title: Crown Princess Mette-Marit of Norway smells a can of 'invisible silence' in Frankfurt
text:
Crown Princess Mette-Marit of Norway smelled a can of 'invisible Silence' today as she visited Germany for the opening ceremony of the Frankfurt Book Fair.

The royal, 46, who is married to Crown Prince Haakon, the heir apparent to the Norweigan throne, joined her husband and Norway's Prime Minster Erna Solberg to interact with the installation from artists Sissel Tolaas and Reling Kagge.

The mother-of-three, looked delighted to be at the event, as she sported a navy dress with a curved neckline and knee-length A-line pleats for the trip.

Crown Princess Mette-Marit of Norway smelled of 'Invisible Silence' today as she visited Germany for the opening ceremony at the Frankfurt Book Fair

The royal, 46, (second right) who is married to Crown Prince Haakon (second left) the heir apparent to the Norweigan throne, sported fitted navy dress as she joined her husband and Norway's Prime Minster Erna Solbert (right). Left: The director of the Buchmesse, Juergen Boos

The installation is part of an exhibition at this years book fair, where you can also smell things like 'Death of grandmother, soon after'.

Showing of a penchant for sparkling jewellery, Princess Mette-Marit sported chunky rose-shaped earrings and two dazzling rings, as well as a shimmering diamond tennis bracelet.

Mette-Marit kept her make-up to a minimum sporting a light layer of foundation and a subtle smokey eye to complement her deep pink lip gloss.

Continuing to reign high in the style stakes, the future queen kept her hair in a well-coiffed do, allowing soft blonde waves to stop at her shoulders.

The 2019 fair, which is among the world's largest book fairs, will be open to the public from October 16-20

Last year, the Crown Princess Mette-Marit, 46, revealed she was suffering from a life-limiting condition called chronic pulmonary fibrosis, in which scar tissue forms in the lungs, and can cause serious breathing problems.

The mother-of-three released her own statement following the diagnosis where she spoke of her determination to carry on as normal.

She said: 'Although such a diagnosis in times will limit my life, I'm glad that the disease has been discovered so early.

'My goal is still to work and participate in the official programme as much as possible.'

As well as her two children with Prince Haakon, she also has a son Marius Borg Høiby, from a previous relationship.
